docs.lead_paragraph: A report in the Prescriptions column on Saturday about a drug-labeling provision in the Senate health committee's legislation on health care misidentified the senator who drafted the provision. Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, wrote the measure, which would require the Food and Drug Administration to consider adding statistics about risks and benefits to drugs' labels. It was not drafted by Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland. (She helped add the measure to a section in the legislation involving health care quality.)
docs.abstract: Correction of Nov 7 article about drug-labeling provision in Senate health committee's legislation on health care, regarding reference to senator who drafted provision

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he expected to bring major health care legislation to the floor next week and to complete work on the bill before Christmas. But other Democratic leaders said it was unlikely that a bill could reach President Obama's desk by year's end. The House approved its version of the health care legislation late Saturday by a vote of 220 to 215. In a first procedural step toward Senate debate, Mr. Reid on Tuesday night moved to put the House bill on the Senator calendar, from which he could call it up any time after Tuesday.

headline.main: Reid Says Health Bill Will Be Done by Christmas

docs.abstract: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid says he expects health care legislation to be done by Christmas; House has approved its version and, in first procedural step toward Senate debate, Reid moves to put House bill on Senator calendar; he has not finalized Senate version and is waiting for additional analysis by Congressional Budget Office; some Democratic leaders are skeptical that bill will reach Pres Obama by year end; photos (M)

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN; Robert Pear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: The sole House Republican to vote in favor of the health care legislation, Representative Anh Cao of Louisiana, said Tuesday in a telephone interview that he had been getting some ''pretty nasty responses.'' The House approved the health care bill late Saturday night on a vote of 220 to 215. Mr. Cao was the only one of 177 House Republicans to vote for it. Afterward, he said he had studied the legislation and concluded that voting for it was the best decision for his New Orleans district, traditionally a Democratic stronghold.
docs.abstract: Rep Anh Cao, sole House Republican to vote in favor of health care legislation, gets mixed response from his constituents in New Orleans; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Liberal interest groups in favor of overhauling the health care system are taking different tacks in trying to advance their goals, at least as far as advertising goes. MoveOn.org is spending $500,000 on television commercials to criticize Democrats who voted against the House bill on Saturday night. The targets include Jason Altmire of Pennsylvania and Heath Shuler of North Carolina, both of whose districts voted for John McCain for president in 2008. (MoveOn, though, is also planning some ''thank you'' events this week for House Democrats who did support the bill.)
docs.abstract: Liberal interest groups take different tacks to advance goals; some are buying television commercials criticizing Democrats who voted against House bill; some are spending money on advertisements thanking 20 Democrats who voted for bill; ads are meant to encourage them to vote in favor when bill comes back for final passage; photo (S)
